projectDesc.p: To the tune “Southland Song”—"In the Sky"is part of The Global Medieval Sourcebook, a digital compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. This larger project comprises computer-readable transcriptions and/or editions of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century, and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia; accompanied by new English translations; high-resolution digital images of manuscript/early print sources, where available; an apparatus that includes critical introductions, textual notes and annotations; and a flexible user interface with which to navigate these materials.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.rdg: To the tune “Southland Song”—"In the Sky"
In the sky, the Starry River turns;
In the human world, the curtain droops.
The autumn chill rises from my pillow and my tears spread more and more around the mat.
I sit up to untie my silk gown, and ask
what time of night it is.
The emerald that adorned the lotus seed-pod is smaller;
The gold that covered the lotus leaves is sparse.
